World Men's Handball Championship|2011]] |} The arena has also hosted a semifinal of [[Melodifestivalen]] every year since the introduction of the current format, except for 2002 itself. It was also considered to host the final of [[Melodifestivalen 2010]], but scheduling conflicts ruled this out.{{cite web|url=http://www.dn.se/kultur-noje/musik/schlagerstaderna-for-nasta-ar-klara-1.939332|title=Schlagerstäderna för nästa år klara|last=Forsell|first=Mikael|date=2009-08-27|work=[[Dagens Nyheter]]|accessdate=2009-08-27}} The arena hosts the annual [[Göteborg Horse Show]] every year since 1977. The arena has hosted concerts by many famous artists, spanning many different genres. Some of the first major concerts to take place at the venue were performed by [[The Who]], [[Deep Purple]] and [[Led Zeppelin]] during their 1972 and 1973 European Tours respectively. [[Iron Maiden]] have performed at the arena the most with a total of nine times with the latest being in 2006. The arena was among one of the four potential candidate venues to host the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2013]].{{cite web|last=Gustavsson|first=Rikard|title=The bidding has started!|url=http://www.esctoday.com/?p=36444|publisher=ESCToday.com|accessdate=28 May 2012|date=28 May 2012}} In the end, the [[Malmö Arena]] was chosen to host the contest. == References == {{reflist|2}} == External links == {{Commons category|Scandinavium}} *[http://www.scandinavium.se/ Scandinavium] — Official site *[http://www.frolundaindians.com/ Frölunda Indians] — Official site *[http://www.goteborghorseshow.com/ Göteborg Horse Show] — Official site *[http://www.framtiden.se/ Förvaltnings AB Framtiden] — Official site {{s-start-collapsible|header={{s-sta|et}}}} {{succession box | title=[[European Indoor Championships in Athletics]]

{{Redirect|Talent scout|talent scouting in the music industry|artists and repertoire}} {{cleanup|reason=the article requires sport-specific content in sections, detailed referencing and 'notable scouts' should be removed as an uninformative list|date=October 2016}} {{Globalize |date = December 2009|discuss=Talk:Scout (sport)#Globalize }}
In [[professional sports]], '''scouts''' are experienced talent evaluators who travel extensively for the purposes of watching athletes play their chosen sports and determining whether their set of skills and talents represent what is needed by the scout's organization. Some scouts are interested primarily in the selection of ''prospects'', younger players who may require further development by the acquiring team but who are judged to be worthy of that effort and expense for the potential future payoff that it could bring, while others concentrate on players who are already polished professionals whose rights may be available soon, either through [[free agent|free agency]] or trading, and who are seen as filling a team's specific need at a certain position. ''Advance scouts'' watch the teams that their teams are going to play in order to help determine [[strategy]].
Many scouts are former [[coach (sport)|coaches]] or retired players, while others have made a career just of being scouts. Skilled scouts who help to determine which players will fit in well with an organization can be the major difference between success and failure for the team with regard to wins and losses, which often relates directly to the organization's financial success or lack thereof as well.
==Kinds of scouts== Scouts tend to have to perform one of two tasks, either scouting opposition teams to research the opposition's players and tactics, or scouting individual players to identify their level of skill and to keep track of potential new signings.<ref>{{cite news|last=Owen|first=Gareth|title=Scouting missions broaden horizons during injury absence|url=http://www.thisisstaffordshire.co.uk/Gareth-Owen-Scouting-missions-broaden-horizons/story-14165404-detail/story.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130505113709/http://www.thisisstaffordshire.co.uk/Gareth-Owen-Scouting-missions-broaden-horizons/story-14165404-detail/story.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=5 May 2013|accessdate=17 December 2011|newspaper=[[The Sentinel (Staffordshire)|The Sentinel]]|date=17 December 2011}}</ref>
Contemporary [[Major League Baseball]] teams usually classify scouts and their differing responsibilities as follows: *'''Advance scouts''' follow the MLB clubs that their team is scheduled to play and file reports on trends and tendencies that influence pitching, defensive, offensive and game strategy. *'''Major League scouts''' and '''professional scouts''' (the most senior of whom are sometimes called "special assignment scouts" or "special assistants to the [[general manager (baseball)|general manager]]") typically track active players under contract to other teams for potential acquisition. They also may support advance scouts or evaluate competing minor league organizations. Per their designation, the former follow players in MLB, while "pro scouts" work [[minor league baseball|minor league]] and [[independent league baseball]]. *'''Amateur scouts''' evaluate [[high school]] and [[college baseball]] players and prepare their MLB teams for the [[Major League Baseball Draft|June amateur draft]]. To ensure that players are seen by multiple evaluators, amateur scouts are usually divided into area scouts, regional cross-checkers and national cross-checkers. *'''International scouts''' cover players not from the [[United States]], [[Puerto Rico]] and other [[insular areas|U.S. territories]], or [[Canada]]. These players are signed as international [[free agent]]s and are not subject to the June draft, although bonus amounts and signing regulations are governed by the collective bargaining agreement between MLB and its [[Major League Baseball Players Association|players' union]]. In addition to the [[Dominican Republic]], [[Venezuela]], [[Mexico]], and other [[Latin America]]n and [[Caribbean]] countries, where MLB teams have had a scouting presence since the mid-20th century, the growth in international baseball has compelled most teams to station scouts in [[Japan]], [[Korea]] and other [[Asia]]n countries, [[Australia]], and [[Europe]].
According to [[Tony Lucadello]], considered by some to be the greatest scout ever,<ref>Robbins, Mike (2004). ''Ninety Feet from Fame: Close Calls With Baseball Immortality''. Pp. 99–100.</ref><ref>Jordan, David M. (2004). ''Occasional Glory: The History of the Philadelphia Phillies''. Pp. 163–164.</ref><ref>Spivak, Jeffrey (2005). ''Crowning the Kansas City Royals: Remembering the 1985 World Series Champs''. P. 36.</ref><ref>Joyce, Gare. ''Wall of Dreams.''</ref> the four kinds of scouts start with the letter 'P':
* '''Poor''' – wastes time looking for games rather than having a planned itinerary * '''Picker''' – emphasizes a player's one weakness to the neglect of all strengths and ignores the potential within * '''Performance''' – bases his evaluation on what a player does in his presence * '''Projector''' – envisions what a player will be able to do in two or three years
Lucadello estimated that five percent of scouts were poor, five percent pickers, 85 percent performance scouts and five percent projectors.<ref>Winegardner, Mark (1990). ''Prophet of the Sandlots: Journeys with a Major League Scout''. P. 97.</ref>
==Computer-aided scouting== {{Main|Computer-aided scouting}}
Modern day scouts are becoming more and more reliant on computer programs to aid and assist in the evaluation of talent being scouted.{{cn|date=October 2016}} Many professional sport clubs now use computers to organize their collected information and data.{{cn|date=October 2016}} Most sports still depend on human management to decide which players their organization will draft or sign.{{cn|date=October 2016}}
==Notable scouts== ===Baseball=== [[Image:Scouts.jpg|thumb|right|Baseball scouts at a game at [[Turner Field]] in 2008.]] *[[Hugh Alexander (baseball)|Hugh Alexander]] *[[Joe Devine (scout)|Joe Devine]] *[[Amanda Hopkins]] *[[Edith Houghton]] *[[Paul Krichell]] *[[Tony Lucadello]] *[[Bobby Mattick]] *[[Ray Shore]] *[[Joe Sugden (baseball)|Joe Sugden]]
===American football=== *[[Rich Behm]] — [[Dallas Cowboys]] scouting assistant who was permanently paralyzed from the waist down after his spine was severed in the May 2009 collapse of the Cowboys training facility. *[[Steve Belichick]] — late assistant coach and scout for the [[Navy Midshipmen football|United States Naval Academy]], author of ''Football Scouting Methods'' (1962), and father of the [[Bill Belichick|NFL coach]]. *[[Dick Haley]] — architect of 1970's [[Pittsburgh Steelers]] dynasty *[[Bill Nunn (American football)|Bill Nunn]] — legendary scout for [[Pittsburgh Steelers]]<ref name="Nunn">{{cite web|url=http://www.newpittsburghcourieronline.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1380:incomplete-journey&catid=42:sports&Itemid=41|title=Incomplete journey |last=Bruce|first=Aubrey|date=February 11, 2010|publisher=[[New Pittsburgh Courier]]|accessdate=12 March 2010}}</ref>
===Basketball=== *[[Will Robinson (basketball)|Will Robinson]]- also scouted for the [[NFL]]'s [[Detroit Lions]]. *[[Kevin Mackey]], [[Indiana Pacers]]
===Association football (soccer)=== {{main|Scout (association football)}} *[[Piet de Visser (football manager)|Piet de Visser]] *[[Geoff Twentyman]] *[[Les Kershaw]] *[[Jack Hixon]] *[[Marco Zunino]] *[[Liam Brady]] *[[Pierluigi Casiraghi]] *[[Jorge Alvial]]
===Ice hockey=== *[[Håkan Andersson (ice hockey)|Håkan Andersson]] *[[Garnet Bailey]] *[[Mike Liut]] *[[Bobby Orr]]

McFarland & Company, 2003. {{ISBN|0-7864-1260-7}} * Robbins, Mike, ''Ninety Feet from Fame: Close Calls With Baseball Immortality''. Carroll & Graf Publishers, 2004. {{ISBN|0-7867-1335-6}} * Spivak, Jeffrey. ''Crowning the Kansas City Royals: Remembering the 1985 World Series Champs.'' Sports Publishing LLC, 2005. {{ISBN|1-58261-826-7}} * Winegardner, Mark. ''Prophet of the Sandlots: Journeys with a Major League Scout''. Prentice Hall Press, 1990. {{ISBN|0-13-726373-2}}

revision.text:
'''Volata''' ("flow") is a [[code of football]] developed and promoted by [[Italian fascists]] for a brief period during the late 1920s and early 1930s, in an attempt to displace sports with non-Italian origins, such as [[association football]] (soccer) and [[rugby union]].
Association football was popular in [[Italy]] when the fascists came to power in 1921. [[Rugby union]] was a new and relatively minor sport, but also growing in popularity.
Although the fascists idealized association football for its contribution to physical fitness, it was also seen at the time as an "English game" (because the rules had been codified by the English [[Football Association]] and the first organized matches had taken place in England). The fascists generally distanced themselves from cultural practices with foreign roots.
Conversely, rugby was seen as having links to the extinct Ancient Roman game of ''[[harpastum]]''. By 1927, fascist propaganda actively promoted rugby – which it referred to as ''palla ovale'' ("oval ball"). However, the ''[[Federazione Italiana Rugby]]'' proved resistant to manipulation and the fascists quickly ceased their support.
The national secretary of the Fascist Party, [[Augusto Turati]], devised volata. Officially, the rules were based on long-extinct codes of football indigenous to Italy, especially the Roman [[harpastum]] and the medieval ''[[calcio Fiorentino]]''. Volata was contested by eight-member sides, with rules that were described by a 1929 propaganda newsreel from ''[[Istituto Luce]]'' as a "synthesis of the essential elements of the games of ''calcio'' and rugby" (''sintesi di elementi essenziali del giuoco del calcio e del "rugby"'').<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ie7y2DSkfW0 ''Istituto Luce'', 1929, ''Partita di "volata" allo stadio del P.N.F. di Roma''] (1 September 2016).</ref> Use of the word "''calcio''" was ambiguous, as it was the usual name of association football, as well as ''calcio Fiorentino'', which in 1930 was also revived at the fascists' behest.
Promoted by Fascist sporting and cultural organizations, Volata enjoyed a brief phase of popularity. More than 100 Volata clubs and a league were reportedly formed.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} However, the enduring popularity of association football caused the fascists to change their attitude toward the sport.
In 1933, volata organizations and competitions were officially abandoned. Afterwards the fascists encouraged association football; Italy hosted and won the [[1934 FIFA World Cup|1934 World Cup]].
The popularity of rugby and its place within Italian sporting culture appear to have been reduced by the changing policies of the fascists, as well as the invention of volata. Nevertheless, rugby survived the fascist period and began to grow when Italy was occupied by British Commonwealth forces during 1943–47.
==See also== *[[Harpastum]] *[[Calcio Fiorentino]] *[[Football in Italy#History|History of association football in Italy]] *[[Rugby union in Italy#History|History of rugby in Italy]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
* ''Making the Rugby World: Race, Gender, Commerce'' edited by Timothy J L Chandler and John Nauright ({{ISBN|0-7146-4853-1}}). See especially pages 92–94. Book page: [https://books.google.com/books?ie=UTF-8&vid=ISBN0714648531&id=bT4R23yidcEC&dq=volata&pg=PP1&printsec=0&lpg=PP1&sig=S-Ow7exL5UdLjL-x0PxYFVvs2hc] * ''National Pastime: How Americans Play Baseball and the Rest of the World Plays Soccer'' by Stefan Szymanski, Andrew S Zimbalist ({{ISBN|0815782586}}) Book Page: [https://books.google.com/books?ie=UTF-8&vid=ISBN0815782586&id=9XzfPqTH7kcC&pg=RA1-PA69&lpg=RA1-PA69&dq=volata&sig=Bjwle9xOaj_lz3Ph1grtrJi5lx0]
{{Hybrid sport}} {{Team sports}}
